author: Azunyan420
body:
nah, it's more like they subsidized the digital-only one because Sony no longer sells game keys for their consoles. What does that mean? Well, it basically means that if you buy the one for 100 bucks cheaper, you're locked into ONE storefront for all your games, and that storefront is controlled and owned entirely by Sony. So that means their margins on that storefront are higher - no disc production or distribution costs or cut to any other retailers. 

Basically...they're trying to be Steam/Origin/Epic. But since they don't sell keys to their games, no gray market shenanigans like occurs with those. No greenmangaming sales to compete directly with. No discounts at all, if they decide they don't want to (but more likely their discounts will just be fewer and farther between as is the case right now). It's a smart play.

author: hartsdad
body:
Each morning, wake up about 30 minutes before the market opens. Keep an eye on “movers” that have already gained a lot AND have a large increase in volume in that 30 minute window. Usually the stocks with the greatest premarket gains are the ones with the most volume. Go all in just before the market opens. Immediately place a limit sell order for a 3%, 5%, 7% gain (whatever you are comfortable with). 9/10 times you’ll hit that target. Even if you start with a very small amount, you will start to make real money very soon.

Even if it’s a pump and dump, you can still ride the FOMO on the way up, but you NEED to sell at your target.

Never hold anything in your “trading” account overnight.

The key is to be OK with seeing a small gain for the day even if that stock continues to shoot up after you sell. Don’t try to “read” the chart to maximize gain. Just set a percentage goal and immediately place the sell order. If you can stick to the plan and not give in the FOMO you are very likely to succeed. You cannot be greedy. You need to understand that eventually 3% or 5% will be a lot of money for one day. 

This is not a “Lambo” strategy, it is a sustainable long term strategy for additional income.

Also, be ready to sell at a loss if the stock goes down. You’ll never win every trade every time, you just have to win more trades than you lose. As long as you stick to a 10% threshold (up or down), you’ll never completely lose your shirt.

Also, be sure to set aside what you will owe for short term capital gains, which are taxed at the regular income rate.

ETA: This strategy is completely separate from an “investment” strategy. In an investment strategy, never buy penny stocks as a long term hold. Buy the Large Cap boring stuff and watch your portfolio slowly gain instead of slowly bleed out while you hope and wait for a moon launch. You might get lucky, but you probably won’t. 

-Trade penny stocks for extra income.
-Invest in proven companies for long term growth. 

I just handed you the keys to success.

author: awertheim
body:
> you can’t get rid of any

You can actually "get rid" of bitcoin by sending it to an address that provably has no key to "unlock" it. It's called "burning" and results in even more scarcity over time as people lose their keys to their addresses or make mistakes in sending to incorrect addresses.

author: schwiz
body:
I've been using nexo, celcius and crypto\_com holding a variety of cryptos and stable coins. I just simply park them there and collect interest, no leveraging with derivatives or anything like that. While I like that cryto will appreciate on its own in my hardware wallet I like earing 4-18% much, much better even if it does in some regards increase the risk. (while lowering other risk such as being a dumbass and losing my keys). 

I really like all 3 services I have tried and each are better than others in some regards. Nexo is cool because it compounds daily and also has free withdraw they even pay network fee. Celcius also pays network fee. CDC has the really cool card, with awesome perks and the amazing 18% on their native token that has also been appreciating very well.

author: InvestorCJ
body: When I first started trading, I started with a attainable goal in my mind. I target 15% compounded annually and in 20 years, if I maintain this, my account will be over 400k. I think 400k over 20 years is to slow of growth in my opion but it would be consistency to meet that. My true goal would to be at 1 million in 10 years which would need to be 45% annually. I like the idea of having two goals one to reach and then another to strive for! I would also like to branch off trading income into other revenue sources like real estate and so on. I am only 21 so I have alot of time ahead of me. I also still work a job since I think multiple sources of income is one of the keys to success. Also, it is nice having guaranteed income as well. I have passed 15% already this year so some years may be better than others.

author: almostmicrochip
body:
i wash cars 

when we finish washing a car in the back we take it round front and park it by the fence. then bring the keys inside and move on to the next one.

i hand him the keys and as i’m about to walk away he hands me 5 dollars

ive never had a customer give me money so i was really confused and just looked at him and said “don’t worry about it, i don’t need that.”



this old dude looks me in the eye and says


“nobody needs it.”


🤯 🤯 🤯 


what a badass

author: discodropper
body:
Pretty much everyone will list off some of the household names in big tech, like AAPL, MSFT, AMZN, ADBE, GOOGL, etc. All of these are industry leaders with solid financials, so they’re probably a safe bet for long-term growth. Though they may be overvalued right now (pretty much everything is). 

Other than those, within tech I tend to like semiconductors. I figure that cloud computing, AI, AR/VR, self-driving cars, fintech, bitcoin mining, smart phones and computers, etc. are just going to become a bigger and bigger part of the economy. And computer chips (CPUs, GPUs, SSDs, those chips in your credit card, etc.) are at the heart of all of these technologies. It’s pretty clear that technological progress here isn’t slowing, and demand for chips is just going to continue to grow. If you want to go with individual companies, NVDA, AMD, TSM, AMAT, MU, LRCX are all at the forefront right now, and have solid balance sheets. If you don’t want to put all your money on one horse, a non-diversified, semiconductor-focused ETF like SMH or SOXX will give you exposure here while mitigating some of the risk. 

Green/clean energy is a promising market, but it’s a really young industry so there’s a lot of risk in trying to pick a winner. TSLA is ahead of the pack for now, but it’ll have competitors nipping at it’s heals soon enough, and the stock is currently way overvalued. There are also other sectors of this market that TSLA hasn’t tapped into, and could see massive growth in the next 5-15 years as we begin to wean off of fossil fuels. Again, a focused ETF like PBW or QCLN is a good way to mitigate risk and broaden exposure without having to pick a single winner. That said, this sector may be overvalued right now because oil/gas have taken a big hit during COVID and green energy isn’t quite ready for prime time. In other words, oil/gas are currently cheap and will probably rebound a bit Post-COVID, so you could make money with fossil fuels, but I’d stay out of them long-term and bet on clean energy/vehicles instead. 

I also like biotech and genomic medicine. TMO is a blue chip that basically has a monopoly and is a go-to for all biological research. Pretty safe bet on a well run company that’ll be around for years. LZAGY, RHHBY, and TECH are similar, but tend to have their hands in more clinical trials and drug development, mainly with small molecules and other ‘classic’ treatment methods. I’m sure there’s a good ETF in this sector, but I haven’t really looked as it’s my field. CRISPR, gene therapy, etc. are all starting to show promise in the clinic, but is a really nascent industry. MRNA and BNTX are probably overvalued right now due to COVID speculation, but if they can get their delivery mechanisms to work (and they’re showing promise), they’ll basically revolutionize medicine. Again, if you don’t want to bet on a single horse, ARKG is a good ETF for genomic medicine. TNX is a very young company that’s showing a lot of promise for sequencing technology, so high risk but potentially very high reward. 

Other than that, it’s always a good idea to put money into ‘boring’ non-risky, non-tech stocks. COST, WMT will probably be good picks during the coming economic crisis, and may actually be able to compete with AMZN if they shore up their online interface. V and MC are solid standbys (can’t go wrong with credit cards). Also probably a safe bet to go with health insurance companies. SPY is also a broadly diversified ETF (basically the tracks the S&P) that will be a safe bet long-term.

My suggestion would be to pick industries you think will grow long-term, and select a few stocks or an ETF within them. Set up a rather diversified portfolio so you aren’t overexposed on any one front (I’ve lost more than the market with this last slump, for instance, since I’m overexposed in tech; I could probably use more ‘boring’ stocks like WMT). One or two shares apiece from 50 promising companies is a much safer bet than 500 shares in one or two very promising companies. Keep each at a smallish percentage of your total (I get really uncomfortable if a single stock goes above 10% of my total, even if it began as 1%, so I sell to bring it back down and use the profit to diversify). Generally speaking, the riskier the industry/company is, the lower percentage of your total it should be. 

Hope this helps!

author: UnpolishedPleb
body:
Ah yes all the classic comments about the “tech bubble” and how everything is overvalued. Guess what... “tech” is literally a part of our daily lives now. 

In the dotcom times it was all about lofty valuation on the possibility that tech would be the next big sector. Turns out many years later to actually be true and everyone is pissed off that they were wrong about doubting it. 

Now Apple, and Microsoft are literally at the top of the S&P500 yet some people still cannot accept them because of P/E valuations and it’s logical but I think its hilarious how contradictory some of the statements can be. 

These people talk about how its impossible to time the market or that past performance doesn’t indicate future performance yet there is one thing they are certain of. A tech bubble because of the tech bubble that happened 20 years ago. How can everyone be so certain these companies are overvalued when the sector has lead the market for the last 10 years. Maybe tech will fall back or maybe it will continue to outperform for another 10 years. We just don’t know. What’s certain is tech is not what it was 20 years ago and it will be interesting to see how it grows going forward. Those who say techs outperformance isn’t relevant just want to rationalize their bearish stance on tech IMO.  

All this said the tech sector is  broad and there are fairly valued solid companies out there with good balance sheets. TSM(P/E 27.4) and LRCX(P/E 20.9) are some I am interested in.

author: BumbleFuckDuck
body:
Article from link:

"Zomedica Pharmaceuticals Corp. (NYSE American: ZOM) announced today that it has agreed with its development partner Qorvo Biotechnologies, LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of Qorvo US, Inc., to develop three new assays -- Cobalamin, cPL (canine Pancreatic Lipase), and Folate -- to target diagnosis of canine gastrointestinal issues. The new assays are in addition to the initial five assays currently under development, including panels for adrenal and thyroid testing, for TRUFORMA™, Zomedica's point-of-care veterinary diagnostic platform. The agreement to pursue development of the new assays has triggered the final $2 million milestone payment under Zomedica’s Development and Supply Agreement with Qorvo.

“Our intent for TRUFORMA™ always has been to have it serve as a broad diagnostic point-of-care tool for dogs and cats and to continue to expand the diagnostic offerings available on the platform," said Robert Cohen, Interim Chief Executive Officer of Zomedica. "We believe that the combination of the Cobalamin, cPL and Folate assays will enable veterinarians to use TRUFORMA to conduct a thorough testing panel to diagnose dogs in gastrointestinal distress."

If successfully developed, the Cobalamin, cPL, and Folate assays will represent what the Company believes is the first non-infectious gastrointestinal panel optimized for use in canines fully available at the point-of-care to facilitate rapid diagnosis of gastrointestinal disorders. Evaluation of the health of different components of the gastrointestinal system is necessary to identify the cause of clinical symptoms. This panel is intended to assay the function of the pancreas, proximal small intestine, and distal small intestine. The Company believes that the ability to conduct testing at the point-of-care will facilitate real-time clinical decision-making, reduce in-patient clinic stay, promote earlier detection and treatment, and increase pet owner satisfaction.

According to a DVM360 study*, ASPCA Pet Insurance, Embrace, Nationwide, Pets Best and Trupanion agree that “GI condition” is the most common insurance claim for dogs. Signs of digestive system disease can include excessive drooling, diarrhea, constipation, vomiting or regurgitation, loss of appetite, bleeding, abdominal pain and bloating, straining to defecate, shock, and dehydration. The TRUFORMA diagnostic device, which is smaller than a desktop printer, is anticipated to provide highly sensitive, species-specific assays using Qorvo’s proprietary, non-optical Bulk Acoustic Wave ("BAW") sensor technology. The BAW sensor is a proven semiconductor technology used in telecommunications and aerospace markets. The Company believes that BAW technology has the potential to improve veterinary diagnostics by delivering reference laboratory accuracy and test performance to the veterinary clinic at the point-of-care."

I bolded the important parts. This is a long hold regardless if r/s happens or does not. IMO the r/s ain't happening.

author: dudeitsadell
body:
I'm actually bullish on semiconductors and feel like theyre the next sector to pop up... the last tech run in august was mostly cloud, aapl, tsla, internet services. Only NVDA and broadcom saw a slight bump. 

Hardware like $QRVO, $QCOM, $INTC, $AMD, $SWKS, $WDC, $MU, $TSM has some ground to make up. The sector rotation cant go to airlines or financials, so Semis and Retail it is
